dataset.title: The Sierra Lakes Inventory Project: Non-Native fish and community composition of lakes and ponds in the Sierra Nevada, California

creator.organizationName: University of California - Santa Barbara, Sierra Nevada Aquatic Research Laboratory
University of California - Santa Barbara, Sierra Nevada Aquatic Research Laboratory
University of California - Santa Barbara, Sierra Nevada Aquatic Research Laboratory

associatedParty.organizationName: Pacific Southwest Research Station, U.S. Forest Service
associatedParty.role: Developed original study design with R. Knapp, involved in study during initial phase of project (1995-1998).

associatedParty.organizationName: University of California - Santa Barbara, Sierra Nevada Aquatic Research Laboratory
associatedParty.role: During initial phase of project (1995-1997), developed GIS coverages of water bodies within the study area. Developed the SLIP database.

abstract.para: The Sierra Lakes Inventory Project (SLIP) was a research endeavor that ran from 1995-2002 and has supported research and management of Sierra Nevada aquatic ecosystems and their terrestrial interfaces. We described the physical characteristics of and surveyed aquatic communities for > 8,000 lentic water bodies in the southern Sierra Nevada, including lakes, ponds, marshes, and meadows. We also created digital map layers for these water bodies when such layers did not exist. The original objective of SLIP was to describe impacts of non-native fish on lake communities, but SLIP data has subsequently enabled study of additional ecological issues, including regional amphibian declines and their impacts on communities, and impacts of non-native fish on terrestrial species. In addition, these data are being used to develop fish removal efforts to restore aquatic ecosystems and recover endangered amphibians. The SLIP data is stored in a relational database that collectively describes water bodies (e.g., depth, elevation, location), surveys (conditions, effort), and communities (including approximately 170 fish, amphibian, reptile, benthic macroinvertebrate, and zooplankton taxa).

keywordSet.keyword: University of California Natural Reserve System (UC NRS)

dataset.intellectualRights: This information is released under the Creative Commons license - Attribution - CC BY (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/). The consumer of these data ("Data User" herein) is required to cite it appropriately in any publication that results from its use. The Data User should realize that these data may be actively used by others for ongoing research and that coordination may be necessary to prevent duplicate publication. The Data User is urged to contact the authors of these data if any questions about methodology or results occur. Where appropriate, the Data User is encouraged to consider collaboration or co-authorship with the authors. The Data User should realize that misinterpretation of data may occur if used out of context of the original study. While substantial efforts are made to ensure the accuracy of data and associated documentation, complete accuracy of data sets cannot be guaranteed. All data are made available "as is." The Data User should be aware, however, that data are updated periodically and it is the responsibility of the Data User to check for new versions of the data. The data authors and the repository where these data were obtained shall not be liable for damages resulting from any use or misinterpretation of the data. Thank you.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: SLIP includes data collected in the southern Sierra Nevada ecoregion in California, USA. This includes the federal jurisdictions of Yosemite National Park, Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks, Inyo National Forest, and Sierra National Forest. These lakes and ponds are located across a broad spatial and elevational gradient (1000 – 4000 m). They are located in several major drainage basins: Tuolumne, Merced, San Joaquin, Kings, Kern, and Owens.

description.para: The Sierra Lakes Inventory Project will not be updated regularly as data collection is completed and maintenance is not planned.

contact.organizationName: University of California - Santa Barbara, Sierra Nevada Aquatic Research Laboratory
University of California - Santa Barbara, Sierra Nevada Aquatic Research Laboratory

description.para: Specific spatial information has been omitted from this dataset due to management restrictions and location of endangered species. This sensitive information is available upon request, but not included in this package.

See the attached document for specific methods: “SNARL_SLIP_Protocol.doc”. This document thoroughly describes all data collection steps. Site selection criteria can also be found in the attached sampling protocol.
To calculate the density of each zooplankton taxon (# per liter), utilize this formula:
[ (sum of counts for taxon across all subsamples) / (number of subsamples) ] /

award.title: Introduced trout in the Sierra Nevada, California: a proposal to study their distribution and impacts on aquatic ecosystems
Faunal surveys of lentic habitats in Sequoia & Kings Canyon National Parks
Faunal surveys of Yosemite National Park’s lentic habitats and their use in understanding impacts of nonnative fish and designing aquatic restoration measures.

dataTable.entityDescription: Amphibian visual survey counts and related data.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Lake ID. Always five digits. This is a primary key field and is never empty.
Survey date. This is a primary key field and is never empty.
Amphibian and reptile species observed. Amphibian and reptile species names may reflect outdated taxonomy that was current at the time of surveys (1995 – 2002).
Eggmass, tadpole, subadult, adult.
Whether counted life stage was alive or dead.
Number observed
Location where observed.

codeDefinition.definition: pools or marshes within 10 m of the feature being surveyed that lack their own Site ID.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Number of each species/life stage collected from site.
Lake ID. Always five digits. This is a primary key field and is never empty.
Collection date. This is a primary key field and is never empty.

Identification date. Identification of the two Branchinecta species based on the following reference: Belk, D., and D. C. Rogers. 2002. Identification of three Branchinecta species (Crustacea : Anostraca) from western North America, with a description of a new species, Hydrobiologia 486:49–55.
Coded last name of person who conducted taxonomic identification
Species of fairy shrimp
Whether a tissue sample for genetic analysis (by Kristy Deiner) was removed from the sample.

textDomain.definition: Whether a tissue sample for genetic analysis (by Kristy Deiner) was removed from the sample.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Lake ID. Always five digits. This is a primary key field and is never empty.

Unique ID for each fish captured per lake. This is a primary key field and is never empty.
Fish species.

codeDefinition.definition: Eggs much smaller than when fully developed.

Reabsorbed. Eggs are reabsorbed (female not able to breed successfully).

dataTable.entityDescription: Visual observation of substrates in water body littoral zone.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Lake ID. Always five digits. This is a primary key field and is never empty.
Survey date. This is a primary key field and is never empty.

Type of littoral substrate. Please refer to protocol for details and methods. Each value represents the tally of transects that were dominated by that substrate type. Types are: silt (<0.5 mm), sand (0.5–2 mm), gravel (>2–75 mm), cobble (>75–300 mm), boulder (>300 mm), bedrock, or woody debris. “Aquatic vegetation” was not an independent substrate category. Instead, each transect was assigned a substrate category (silt, sand, woody debris, etc.) and the number of those transects that also contained aquatic vegetation was also tallied.

codeDefinition.definition: “Aquatic vegetation” was not an independent substrate category. Instead, each transect was assigned a substrate category (silt, sand, woody debris, etc.) and the number of those transects that also contained aquatic vegetation was also tallied.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Number of transects dominated by each substrate type.

codeDefinition.definition: silt (<0.5 mm); sand (0.5–2 mm); gravel (>2–75 mm)

attribute.attributeDefinition: Number of transects dominated by each substrate type.
Lake ID. Always five digits. This is a primary key field and is never empty.
